title: Man with torn bowel and colostomy bag living on food parcels after benefits delay
text:

A man suffering the "worst pain of his life" after ripping his bowel has been left waiting for food parcels after a delay to his benefits.

Lee Strickley from Liverpool now lives with a colostomy bag - and says he has nowhere left to turn.

He was forced to spend eight days in hospital in April because of the stress and poor lifestyle brought on by issues with the Universal Credit system.

The Liverpool Echo report that he was sanctioned by the DWP for missing a job centre appointment - even though he was on an English course that he had been told to go on at the same time.

This "incorrect sanction" led to him falling into spiralling debts as he borrowed money just to try and get by.

(Image: James Maloney/Liverpool Echo)

(Image: James Maloney/Liverpool Echo)

He explained: "I was so stressed and depressed - I took out a budgeting loan and three hardship payments to get by because the sanction left me with nothing. I was eating very badly and feeling terrible.

"One day I thought I had pulled a muscle because of pains I was having - then I woke up in the worst pain of my life and was rushed to hospital in an ambulance."

Lee was in hospital for eight days after developing the condition diverticulitis which had caused a tear in his bowel.

He said: "I ended up having four inches of my bowel removed and now have to live with a colostomy bag.

"The doctors told me the whole situation was brought on by stress - and because of the bad food I was eating, which was all I could get from the foodbank."

But Lee's troubles with benefits and the DWP were set to get even worse.

(Image: James Maloney/Liverpool Echo)

He added: "I don't know why but they said it would take three months to sort the extra money - I still haven't had anything.

"I feel absolutely terrible - I can't get out of the house and have been living on food parcels.

"The doctors told me I need to have a high fibre diet, but I can't afford any decent food, so I'm worried it is making me more ill.

"I can't get out of the house, so I need to pay for taxis just to get to the shops or anything."

He said his situation has taken a terrible toll on his physical and mental health.

He added: "It is all just getting on top of me and I can't take it anymore.

(Image: James Maloney/Liverpool Echo)

"I'm sat here in my house and I've literally got nothing except a can of beans.

"I have been to charities, I have had handouts - I've tried everything but now I have nowhere left to turn."

"It has got so bad - I thought I might not be here at all at some points."

A DWP spokesperson said: “Mr Strickley receives his full Universal Credit entitlement each month. All rent arrears were cleared in May, and his rent continues to be paid directly to his landlord.

“He has also been assessed as having ‘limited capability for work’ and will soon start receiving more than £300 in extra support each month.”
description: Lee Strickley makes a plea for help and says he can't cope any more with his mental health deteriorating
